oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Earl Thomas Conley Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Earl Thomas Conley (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Earl Thomas Conley; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Earl Thomas Conley reflects on his eighteen number one hits and his success as a song writer -- (00:39) "What She is (Is a Women in Love)" is introduced by Conley as a song written Bob McDill and Paul Harrison -- (01:05) Conley calls "That Was a Close One" a song about people who are afraid of love -- (01:21) Biff Collie and Conley joke about fearing a women (01:35) Collie brings up the record of four top tracks on a single album and Conley gives praise to the help he received -- (02:00) Conley talks about his seven siblings and he reflects on those of which went into the music industry -- (02:44) Conley reflects on his first guitar that his mother bought for him (03:10) Collie and Conley introduce "Love Don't Care (Whose Heart it Breaks" as a twist on love -- (03:43) Collie and Conley talk about writing on the road -- (05:07) Collie and Conley discuss "Who's Gonna Tell Her Goodbye" as an acknowledgment that someone has to leave the relationship -- (05:44) Collie asks about Conley's writing and Conley reflects on early artistic energy that was transfer to song writing -- (06:48) Collie asks Conley to sing for him -- (07:05) Conley dedicates "Love Out Loud" to people that struggled with expressing their love and his father -- (07:52) Collie asks Conley to sing again and "I Can't Win For Losin' You" is discussed by Conley as a easy live song -- (08:36) Collie inquires about Conley's song stylistic choices and Conley talks about remaining fresh in song writing -- (10:04) Collie asks about early role models and Conley reflects on 1950's country artists and Charlie Pride -- (11:13) Conley's" Bring Back Your Love To Me" is discussed -- (11:35) Collie inquires about Conley's beard and Conley reflects on his formative years affect on his beard -- (14:00)"What I'd Say" is introduced by Collie and told by Conley as being in love with a girl -- (14:29) Collie brings up unique expression of Conley and Conley reflects on "Go to Hell" -- (15:46) Collie is fascinated with mistaken identity and Conley brings up a recent incident of an officer mistaking him for singing about a boat -- (17:24) Conley talks about, at Collie's request, which version of his name he chose at different points of his life -- (18:28) Collie and Conley reflect on "Chance of Lovin' You" as making your move on love -- (18:57) Conley and Collie reflect on Randy Scruggs and his musical heritage -- (21:02) "You Must Not Be Drinking Enough" by Conley is discussed by Collie and Conley as the greatest country song Conley had ever heard -- (21:58) Conley talks about how the song reflects on an inner voice that seeks to inspire -- (12:28) Collie and Conley reflect on the process after a song has been completed -- (23:52) Collie asks what is next for Conley and Conley reflects on being on the road and the upcoming projects -- (25:09) Collie and Conley speak their departing words
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Conley, Earl Thomas; Collie, Biff;
